title: Liverpool parade collision driver believed to have followed ambulance, say police
snippets:
Man, 53, arrested on suspicion of attempted murder and drug driving, may have tailgated ambulance after road block temporarily lifted

  • Liverpool parade collision – live updates

The driver who ploughed into fans celebrating Liverpool’s Premier League title has been arrested on suspicion of drug driving and attempted murder after he “followed” an ambulance past a roadblock, police have said.

The 53-year-old British man, from the West Derby area of Liverpool, was arrested on suspicion of attempted murder, dangerous driving offences and driving whilst unfit through drugs. He remains in custody where he is being interviewed.

Continue reading...
titles: Liverpool parade collision driver believed to have followed ambulance, say police
summary: A 53-year-old man from West Derby, Liverpool, was arrested for attempted murder and drug driving after crashing into fans at a Liverpool Premier League title celebration. He reportedly tailgated an ambulance through a roadblock before the incident. The suspect remains in custody, facing additional charges of dangerous driving and driving while unfit through drugs.
constructiveness_reason: While the story provides basic awareness of the incident and the actions of the police, it doesn't provide deeper insights, solutions, or empowering knowledge. It's mainly focused on the negative event and the charges against the suspect, without offering much in terms of broader context or implications.

title: What to Know About the Liverpool FC Parade Car Crash
snippets: More than 60 people, including four children, were injured on Monday after a driver plowed into a crowd that had been celebrating Liverpool F.C.’s Premier League title.
titles: What to Know About the Liverpool FC Parade Car Crash
summary: On Monday, a driver crashed into a crowd celebrating Liverpool F.C.'s Premier League victory, injuring over 60 individuals, among them four children.
constructiveness_reason: This story merely reports on a negative event without providing actionable insights, solutions, or a deeper understanding of the situation. It provides basic awareness about the incident but lacks depth or insight.

title: King Charles tells Canada’s parliament country will stay ‘strong and free’ amid Trump annexation threats – live
snippets:
Monarch says Canada ‘faces critical moment’ as address comes amid Trump’s repeated threats that US should make Canada the 51st state

Earlier this morning, Alan Garber, president of Harvard University, told NPR’s Morning Edition that elite institutions need to double down on their “commitment to the good of the nation” and “be firm in our commitments to what we stand for”.

Garber said he finds the measures taken by the Trump administration to be “perplexing”; while he acknowledges there is work to be done on campus regarding viewpoint diversity, he said he struggles to see a link between funding freezes and fighting antisemitism.

I think that we have heard from some people that they do feel that [Harvard lacks viewpoint diversity]. What is perplexing is the measures that they have taken to address these that don’t even hit the same people that they believe are causing the problems. Why cut off research funding? Sure, it hurts Harvard, but it hurts the country because after all, the research funding is not a gift. The research funding is given to universities and other research institutions to carry out work – research work – that the federal government designates as high-priority work. It is work that they want done. They are paying to have that work conducted. Shutting off that work does not help the country, even as it punishes Harvard, and it is hard to see the link between that and, say, antisemitism.

I would say that the federal government has the authority through the budgeting process to reallocate funds. But the question to ask is what problem is [Trump] trying to solve by doing that? The money that goes to research universities in the form of grants and contracts, which is almost all of the federal support that we get, is used to pay for work that we perform at the behest of the government. So in reallocating to some other use, including trade schools, it means that work just won’t be performed. So the right question is, is this the most effective use of federal funding? Do you really want to cut back on research dollars? I’m less concerned about whether it goes to a trade school or if it goes to some other project, like working on highways. The real question is, how much value does the federal government get from its expenditures on research? There is a lot of actual research demonstrating the returns to the American people have been enormous.

I would say that we need to be firm in our commitments to what we stand for. And what we stand for – I believe I speak for other universities – is education, pursuit of the truth, helping to educate people for better futures. And hopefully our own students, after they graduate from our institutions, go out and serve the world. In the end, we’re about producing and disseminating knowledge and serving our nation and our world. When we fail in that, then we can expect to be attacked. So number one, I think we all need to redouble our commitment to the good of the nation and the world. And I know my fellow leaders fully embrace that.

Continue reading...

Monarch says Canada ‘faces critical moment’ as address comes amid Trump’s repeated threats that US should make Canada the 51st state

titles: King Charles tells Canada’s parliament country will stay ‘strong and free’ amid Trump annexation threats – live
King Charles tells Canada’s parliament country will stay ‘strong and free’ amid Trump annexation threats – live
summary: Amid threats from former President Trump to make Canada the 51st U.S. state, Harvard University President Alan Garber emphasized the need for elite institutions to reinforce their commitment to the nation's good. In an NPR interview, Garber expressed confusion over the Trump administration's funding freezes, questioning their effectiveness in addressing issues like antisemitism and viewpoint diversity on campus. He argued that cutting research funding harms both the university and the country, as it stops high-priority government work, ultimately questioning the allocation of federal research

title: Top Stock Movers Now: Tesla, AutoZone, Newmont, and More
snippets:
Key Takeaways

  • U.S. equities took off at midday on word President Donald Trump was delaying new tariffs on European Union imports.
  • Tesla CEO Elon Musk said he would shift his focus away from politics and spend more time on his companies.
  • Falling gold prices sent down shares of Newmont and rival gold miners.


U.S. equities jumped at midday after President Donald Trump said he would delay new tariffs on European Union imports for 90 days. The Nasdaq added 2%, and the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 were up more than 1%.

Tesla (TSLA) shares advanced when CEO Elon Musk said he would move away from politics and be more involved with his businesses.

Shares of Ross Stores (ROST) and Deckers Outdoor (DECK), which had dropped when Trump first announced the tariffs, rallied on the news.

Informatica (INFA) and Salesforce (CRM) shares rose after the firms struck a deal for Salesforce to buy the shares of Informatica it didn't own for $8 billion.

AutoZone (AZO) shares tumbled when the auto parts retailer missed profit estimates on falling demand and foreign currency fluctuations.

Shares of Rocket Pharmaceuticals (RCKT) lost more than half their value and sank to an all-time low when the drugmaker reported a patient taking its experimental treatment for Danon disease died, leading to a halt in the study.

The tariff decision sent the price of gold sliding 2%, and that dragged down shares of Newmont (NEM) and other gold miners.

Oil futures fell. The yield on the 10-year Treasury note dropped. The U.S. dollar gained on the euro, pound, and yen. Most major cryptocurrencies traded higher.
titles: Top Stock Movers Now: Tesla, AutoZone, Newmont, and More
summary: U.S. equities surged after President Donald Trump announced a 90-day delay on new tariffs for European Union imports, leading to significant gains in the Nasdaq, Dow Jones, and S&P 500. Tesla shares rose as CEO Elon Musk committed to focusing more on his businesses rather than politics. The news also positively affected shares of Ross Stores and Deckers Outdoor, which had previously fallen due to the tariff announcement. Salesforce's acquisition of Informatica for $8 billion boosted their shares, while AutoZone's shares dropped due to missed profit estimates. Rocket Pharmaceuticals saw a drama
constructiveness_reason: This story is informative and provides useful context about the impact of political decisions on the stock market. It also provides actionable insights for investors about which stocks are moving and why.

title: The sun is killing off SpaceX's Starlink satellites

titles: The sun is killing off SpaceX's Starlink satellites
summary: The number of satellites orbiting Earth has reached an all-time high, significantly boosted by the deployment of mega constellations such as SpaceX's Starlink internet service. Recent studies have begun to shed light on how solar activity impacts these satellites, indicating a growing need to understand and mitigate space weather effects on the burgeoning satellite infrastructure.
constructiveness_reason: This story provides useful information about the impact of solar activity on satellites, highlighting an emerging issue in the field of space technology. However, it doesn't report on potential solutions or improvements to mitigate these effects, which would have made it more constructive.

title: Microbiology Mystery: Why Do Most Microbes Die in Labs?
snippets: A new study reveals that microbial diversity is shaped by a network of mutual dependencies. Microbial ecosystems are found all around us—in seawater, soil, and even inside the human gut—and they are bursting with an incredible variety of life. Yet, scientists have long faced a frustrating challenge: trying to recreate this rich diversity in the [...]
titles: Microbiology Mystery: Why Do Most Microbes Die in Labs?
summary: A new study has found that the difficulty in recreating microbial ecosystems in laboratory settings, where most microbes die, is due to the complex network of mutual dependencies that shape microbial diversity. These ecosystems, abundant in environments like seawater, soil, and the human gut, thrive on intricate interactions that are hard to replicate outside their natural context.
constructiveness_reason: This story offers a deeper understanding of why most microbes die in labs, providing insight into the complex network of mutual dependencies that shape microbial diversity. It doesn't explicitly mention solutions, but it does highlight a problem that needs to be addressed, contributing to progress in the field.

title: How fast you age is dictated by your sex, ethnicity and education

title: Your Heart May Be Aging Faster Than You Realize – Are You at Risk?
snippets: MRI technology reveals that unhealthy lifestyles can prematurely age your heart by decades. Scientists at the University of East Anglia (UEA) have created a powerful new way to uncover your heart’s true age using a simple MRI scan. This breakthrough can reveal how well your heart is actually functioning, not just how old you are [...]
titles: Your Heart May Be Aging Faster Than You Realize – Are You at Risk?
summary: Scientists at the University of East Anglia have developed a new MRI technology that can determine the true age of your heart, revealing that unhealthy lifestyles may cause it to age prematurely by decades. This advancement offers a more accurate assessment of heart function beyond just chronological age.
constructiveness_reason: This story is highly constructive as it informs readers about a new MRI technology that provides a more accurate assessment of heart function. This could potentially empower readers to make healthier lifestyle choices to prevent premature aging of their heart. The story also raises awareness about the impacts of unhealthy lifestyles on heart health.

title: What Hitting Snooze Every Morning Does to Your Brain
snippets: Despite being frowned upon by sleep experts, hitting the snooze button is a global morning ritual—one embraced by more than half of sleepers in a massive study. From analyzing millions of nights of data, researchers found that snoozing may disrupt crucial REM sleep and make mornings even harder. Waking Up Wrong? The Snooze Button Habit [...]
titles: What Hitting Snooze Every Morning Does to Your Brain
summary: A study analyzing millions of nights of sleep data reveals that over half of sleepers regularly hit the snooze button, a habit sleep experts advise against. Researchers found that using the snooze button can disrupt REM sleep, potentially making it more difficult to wake up and start the day.
constructiveness_reason: This story provides useful insights into the effects of using the snooze button on REM sleep. It increases the reader's understanding of sleep patterns and the potential negative impacts of disrupting them. However, it does not report on solutions or improvements, which is why it doesn't score higher.
